p: In contrast to chronic hepatitis, the parenchymal changes dominate the picture, but there is always some portal inflammation, affecting most or all of the small portal tracts ( Fig. 6.7 ). The density of the infiltrate varies. Interlobular bile ducts may show abnormalities, including irregularity, crowding and stratification of the epithelium, cytoplasmic vacuolation and infiltration by lymphocytes ( Fig. 6.8 ). These changes, together with formation of dense lymphoid structures (aggregates and follicles), are most often seen in hepatitis C. Bile-duct loss (ductopenia) is very rare.
